subject: Re: [junit] Re: re - novice QA
msgSnippet: If I understand it correctly, you are trying to improve your test code to be more junit friendly . If that is the case, I think you should do the following
messageBody:
If I understand it correctly, you are trying to improve your test code to
be more 'junit friendly'.

If that is the case, I think you should do the following incremental
refactoring :
1. change your testing class to extend junit.framework.TestCase

2. Put all your testing code into a method start with 'test', e.g.
public void testCompatibility() so that test runner can pick it up.

3. change the code so that instead of adding an error to a vector,
call fail("your message here") instead. I suggest you change the
first one or three only so that you don't spend too much time and
keep focused.

4. Now you might notice that the first fail will stop further testing. So
you need to create another test method (a public method that
returns void and takes no arguments) and move some code into
that method. The code you move should be the one that you stil
want to do regardless whether the first one fail or not. Don't worry
about duplicate code for now.

5. Now do another one in another method, which should be the code
you want to continue even if the first two tests fail.

6. Now that you have a good idea of the duplicated code, move them
to the setUp() method so that they will be called automatically.

7. Continue the steps. Take care of the setUp and tearDown so that
your tests won't be dependent on each other (they can certainly call
each other, though).

Hopefully this will get you started, unless, of course, I totally
misunderstood your motivation. :)

And keep in mind that this is by no means a trival task. So be
prepared and don't lose your focus. :) Do something like write down
the steps you are going to do.

Shane
